newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Formosa sparks debate on Taiwan's China policy.
newsitem.headline: Formosa sparks debate on Taiwan's China policy.

text.p: Taiwan's cautious investment policy towards China came under fire on Tuesday following cancellation of a major mainland project, with analysts and lawmakers urging more liberalisation despite political risks.
They also criticised the government for failing to enact clear guidelines for investment in rival China, a shortcoming exposed by Formosa Plastics' decision to drop a power plant project.
"Local businesses are told to refrain from temptation and adopt patience. The question is, how long should they wait?" legislator Chen Ching-pao of the ruling Nationalist Party asked parliament.

"The government's mainland policy is ambiguous," said lawmaker Chen Chiung-tsan. "It lacks concrete and detailed planning. What is more, the government does not give local businesses a clear direction."

After a day of uncertainty over the fate of the US$3 billion thermal power station in China's Fujian province, Formosa said on Monday it would respect the government's policy and abandon the giant investment.

Taiwan Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang told reporters that Taiwan had no intention of allowing Formosa to finance the plant, urging Taiwan firms to consider "social responsibility" when investing in the mainland.

Taipei is concerned that its prosperous economy could become too dependent on the mainland, thereby leaving the island politically vulnerable. Some 30,000 Taiwan businesses have poured more than US$30 billion into China since an unofficial thaw in ties began in the 1980s.
Communist China has regarded Nationalist-ruled Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949, vowing to retake the island by force if necessary.
Taiwan forbids direct China investments, obliging firms to route even small investments through Hong Kong or other third territories after obtaining permits from the Economic Ministry.

An opinion poll conducted by the Mainland Affairs Council, Taiwan's top policymaking body towards China, showed more than 50 percent of Taiwan people supported a tougher China policy amid communist leaders' hostility against the island.

Echoing the government's caution, lawmaker Lee Chin-yung of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, compared Taiwan investors' "mainland fever" to the recent outbreak of a deadly and highly contagious hog disease on the island.
"The government should demonstrate the same determination to terminate the economic foot-and-mouth disease as it did on the hog foot-and-mouth disease," Lee said.
But some analysts said the government's cautious attitude towards China investment could dampen business confidence.
The mass circulation United Daily News questioned the government's very commitment to a free economy.

"The government has not had clear guidelines to govern Taiwan businesses' investment in the mainland," the newspaper said. "But it wastes no time to scare companies after their mainland investment projects are made public.
"How can Taiwan claim to be liberalised and internationalised? How can Taiwan's environment be fit for investment?" the daily asked.
Formosa Plastics on Monday appealed to the government not to adopt policies that jeopardised Taiwan's economic growth.

"Taiwan should continue to step up efforts at internationalisation and liberalisation in order to attain continuous growth," the company said. "Economic growth is more important to Taiwan than to other countries."
